text: 12 oz. bottle. Slightly hazy golden body. Smells of sourdough bread, grassy hops, and a slight green apple fruitiness. Tastes of grassy hops up front, a touch of grain behind it that turns into doughy malt flavors. Back end is just a little yeasty with an almost tangy bite, again reminiscent of that sourdough aroma. Finishes with lingering doughy sweetness and spicy hop bitterness after the tang dies down. Light body. I am certainly no expert on this style, but this seems to be pretty damned good.

2017 version. Pours a hazy golden yellow from the bottle with bubbly white head that leaves moderate lace. Aroma of nice pilsner malt and grassy earthy hops. Taste follows, biscuit malt and grassy back end, with a clean creamy mouth. This might be one of the best lagers Ive ever had.

[ Keg ][ 16oz ][ New Glarus ][ $8 ][ NG Pilsner Flute ][ 10.18.16 ]
>> For my 10,000th beer review, I wanted to skip through some of my backlog and post my favorite beer from 2016. New Glarus revived their Zwickel for 2016 and I just so happened to be in Wisconsin and dropped in - what a nice surprise! This was available on tap at the brewery and also to go in 6-packs only at the brewery - no retail distribution. For the side of me that is pilsner/German lager obsessed, NGs Zwickel absolutely nailed it. This is a perfect looking beer in the NG pilsner flute glass: crystal clear golden with ferocious, champagne-like bubbles that never end. The beer is topped by a lasting, meringue white foam. The nose is fresh bread, lemon, and grassy hops. Nothing crazy, but the malt character is perfect. In flavor, this is rich and bready with perfect buoyancy from the high carbonation. The palate is juicy, silky, and super smooth. Thick breadiness piles on and goes a bit lactic in the backend like good sourdough. There is just a touch of sugar and apple sauce. Really, nothing says hoppy in the taste, but the balancing character is there. Its a simple, soft, quenching beer that has a lot of finesse. Maybe its something about drinking this outside in NGs gorgeous Swiss Village/Disneyland-looking immaculate space. I took this beer with me on a little walk through the woods on their trails. Sitting under the trees with chipmunks scurrying around - it was a perfect day.

Pours a hazy straw yellow into New Glarus dimple mug. Apparently this is sold only at New Glarus brewery. Must only be made in small batches. Great biscuits and crackery flavor with a spicy hop profile. Fresh and complex. A yeasty finish with some lemon. Easily one of the best lagers I have ever tried. Surprised they dont feature this as one of the brewerys staple beers.

Very pleasant aroma yeasty dough like and bread bakery hints. appearance pale, golden, slightly hazy, with a minimal white head. taste meadium sweet not bitter at all a light tasting beer. On the palate medium creamy texture with an average carbonation with a long finish. This looks like but is not your average beer. You can tell it is well crafted. Can only be bought at the brewery itself and is a limited addition.

Tasted from bottle. Pours a clean gold with white head. Faint aroma of straw and grains. Taste is mildly sweet with no bitterness. Flavors of crackers, straw, grains. Very sessionable and crisp. Quite nice. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle shared by Jack, thanks! Pours a clear yellow with a white head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has a lot of straw with some biscuit and a sweet grain backbone. Flavor has sweet grains, hay and a bit of biscuit underlying.

12oz bottle from the brewery. Wow. This is a great beer. Filtered orange-tan body, fluffy white head. Clean, doughy malt tones. Lots of depth, but all balanced. Grassy, peppery noble hops. Deep lager notes. Awesome.

12 oz. bottle via trade. Pours a clear gold with a small fizzy white head that settles into a ring that lasts all the way down. Clean and crisp at the start, especially when colder, with straw, cracker, grass, earth, cereal - the Munich malts shine through, with a decent hop snap and some malty and light fruity sweetness. Light-bodied, with moderate carbonation and a malty, sweet, but refreshing mouthfeel. Good Zwickel.

12oz bottle from the local grocery. Pale golden colored pour with a bit of a white head. Aroma has yeast, light straw, some lemon, some biscuit. A touch floral. Taste has light sweet malts, lemon, some doughy-ness. Light to medium bodied. No real alcohol presence. The blend is ok, and the carbonation is constant. Finishes light and short. Better nose than taste, and better than the original version NG made, but still not my thing. 12.4

Bottle picked up from New Glarus. Brilliant gold pour with a large white head. Nose is pretty fresh and vibrant. Baked bread. Some wax and hay bucolic character. Light pepper. Some apricot and white grape fruitiness. Flavor is wonderfully balanced. Crisp, clean malt. Mild toasty biscuit and a bit of honey. Snappy, lightly grassy finish. Soft bitterness. Light body, strong carb. Very good.

Bottled. Poured clear medium golden with a sticky white head. The aroma picked up lemon rind and earthy notes. The flavor found crisp lemon zest and bready notes.. clean finish. Lighter-bodied with a great mouthfeel.. nice one!

Bottle @ home, picked up in Wisconsin. Clear golden appearance with a moderate sized, off white head. Aroma is very herbal- straw, hay, grass- some floral notes and slight effervescence. Medium light body. Off dry. Low to moderate bitterness. Cracker and lightly toasted grain the mouth. Not overly flavorful but super easy drinking and clean. Way better than I expected. Itd be super easy to drink liters of this all day.
12 oz. bottle purchased at the brewery. Poured clear golden, thick white head. Aroma was malts, lemon, grassy. Taste was sweeter, lemon, spice. Nice.
12oz pours a clear gold with a ring of white head. Nose has yeast, corn, malt, biscuit, lemon. Flavor is yeast, lemon, biscuit, mild honey. Dry finish. Solid for the style.
Bottle at the Local DC Tasting. Clear pale yellow with off-white head. Aromas of herbs, light citrus. Tastes of corn, wheat, citrus, light malt. Light body with a dry finish.
12oz bottle at the July DC tasting. Poured a light hazy golden-yellow color with a small white head. Aroma was light malts. Light grain. Fizzy malt character. Crisp.

Ol Uncle Dan sez:

My dumm nephew left his computer open with all his passwords & stuff & so Im going to go see what all this beer rating crap is all about. Jee-zus! You people should oughta get lives! I found out this here beer cost 72 bucks and the fool had to drive an hour to get it, kids 50 year old he should know better by now. Anyhow I guess its pretty good but I can get about 5 30-packs of Keystone for the same price. Enjoy your hobby losers!

Muzzle sez: 

Case of bottles from the brewery. This one sampled 10 minutes out of the fridge in a New Glarus pils glass. Faintly hazy, almost "greasy" pale amber, largish frothy head diminishes moderately slowly to a bit of lasting ring. Very fresh and deep grassy aroma; simple but hugely enticing, this is the essence of a summer lager to me. Outstanding grainy/bready flavor, with just a subtle hint of honey sweetness, light to medium mouthfeel and a brief kiss of lasting dry hoppiness to finish. While its not a hugely complex beer overall, one is left with a very long, lingering enticement to further bottles, and future endeavors from one of Americas great breweries.

Screw Keystone. Hi Ratebeer.
Bottle. Clear yellow color, white head. Straw aroma. Taste has subtle lemon, subtle straw. OK.
Easy drinking and good for style. Light butter and some sweet malt. Golden pour with ok head and lacing. Light sweet malt finish. Bottle.
Gold color and lacing head. Yeast in the aroma. Soft and smooth flavor with a lottlw carbonation bite. Malt and more yeast. Great palate on this beer.

Bottle shared by Bob - thanks! Clear light golden in color with a white head and slight white lacing. Slight earthy hop nose. Bright taste, malty cracker moves quickly into a crisp euro hop thing. Yummy.

12 Oz bottle acquired from The Hilltop Brewery (New Glarus, WI). Glad to grab some of these. Pours a lively dulled golden harvest hue, pretty glow and lively cascading bubbles flow through. Bright white crown on head sits atop, full layer retains and laces well. Aromas show a crisp, cleaner appeal. Bready malts, straw, subtle grass. A faint waft of fruit is subtle. Light, clean, a bit fuzzy and lively. Initial is lighter bodied, gentle bready appeal, smooth and almost a bit creamy. Gentle fruity wafts, earthy hops and mellow yeastiness. Clean and smooth, this one goes down easy. Cereal, bread, some earthiness, a tangy appeal and just enough bitterness into the back. That tangy fruit and yeasty appeal is pleasant. Quite an easy one to put back. Pretty pour, smooth mellow nose. Cleaner and smooth flavors, fresh and subtle sweet and spicy appeal as we flow through. Really simple yet expert stuff.

Picked up a six pack at the brewery in New Glarus, Wisconsin. Pours a clear golden straw colored brew with a creamy white head that has excellent retention and lacing. Aroma of floral hops, golden grain malt, a hint of white bread and touch of angel food cake. Taste is medium bodied with a rich golden malt flavor, noble floral and light grassy hops with some lager yeast. Finish is semi-sweet, a short mild bitterness with rich golden malt and lager yeast aftertaste. For a second I thought this was a revived New Glarus historical beer (Zweifel) but it spelling is different.

12oz bottle to New Glarus glass. They warned of cloudiness but its crystal clear. Fantastic pillows of white foam remain all day. Sweetness from the malt with mild hop bitterness. An absolute all day drinker.

Bottle. Clear as a bell, with soapy white head. Nose is fresh barley, floral, with gentle, crackery malt and a little mint, even. Full, but light mouthfeel, just intensely drinkable. Easily one of New Glarus best in recent memory.

Bottle purchased at the brewery
Wow, who would have thought that such a simple Low-alcohol beer could be rated this high? yes, this guy can! Pours golden yellow hue a pinch darker than an american standard with a nice whipsy white head and sparse ghostly lacing. nose is grainy, slightly sweet, grassy. perfect for the style. Flavors exhibit the grains and pale malts here. palate is slick, full and just perfect for this kind of beer. A fantastic representation of this style. great stuff!

12oz bottle, from the brewery. Thanks Josh! Pours a crystal clear, pale yellow color with a white head and some lacing. Aroma is malty, bread, cereal, hay. Medium on the palate with creamy carbonation. Flavor is sweet, bread, cereal,light grassy hops, some pine, with a crisp, grassy finish. Excellent. Only needs a little bit of yeasty haze to be perfect.

Bottle - One of my big sads is not being around and into beer when New Glarus made their first Zwickel. I was around, thankfully, for the R&D incarnation, which was a glorious beer that kicked me in the nuts, then held me tenderly as I whimpered in pain, caressing me with is soft Noble hops and rustic graininess. I still dream about that beer. This pale yellow number comes close, with its pillowy white head, grainy sweetness, and all that soft floral Noble hoppiness that I yearn for. Hot damn--that smell is just so fine. The taste gets a little muddled, with the grain and hops commingling to produce a little bitterness that isnt what Im looking for in this style. The finish saves it somewhat, coming back with that sticky graininess and a dusty yeastiness. The pale malts just stick in the back of your mouth for awhile, letting you enjoy the beer long after it goes down the hatch. Lovely body, with fluffy carbonation that bites a bit, but compliments the light body. Looks like this guy is going to have to go down to the Beer Depot and pray this is still there.
